映射：世界各地的碳定价举措

过去二十年来，世界各国政府通过各种举措和政策应对气候变化，其中碳定价首当其冲。

最近的一个例子是加拿大安大略省于 2022 年首次启动的排放绩效标准计划。该计划设定了工业设施的年度碳排放限额，并对超额碳排放收取费用。

乔纳森·莱图诺 (Jonathan Letourneau)绘制的这张图表描绘了全球 70 个活性碳定价举措，并强调了2022 年世界银行报告中所见的它们的全球影响。

但首先，让我们看看不同类型的碳定价：

碳税与碳排放交易体系

从广义上讲，碳定价让排放组织可以在减少碳排放和支付碳排放之间做出选择。

用于提供这种选择的两个典型举措是碳税和排放交易系统（ETS）：

  • 碳税：这种税收或征税直接适用于碳排放或释放温室气体的燃料的生产。这使得释放大量碳的产品或服务比更环保的替代品（或减少排放）更加昂贵。
  • 排放交易系统 (ETS) ：也称为限额与交易系统，ETS 对获得许可的行业可以排放的温室气体总量设定了上限。低排放企业可以将未使用的排放配额出售给超过上限的较大排放企业。

鉴于许多国家都制定了雄心勃勃的碳中和目标，欧洲的立场并不令人意外。该地区的欧盟排放交易体系（EU ETS）是世界上最大的碳市场，每年涵盖18亿吨排放量。

加拿大还实施了许多区域和国家碳定价举措，许多省份都属于这两种主要类型的碳定价。例如，不列颠哥伦比亚省是北美第一个实施碳定价的司法管辖区，其碳排放根据碳税和碳排放交易体系进行定价。

与此同时，2021年全球最大的温室气体排放国中国也于同年实施了期待已久的国家碳排放交易体系。仅一年时间，我国碳排放配额交易量就突破2亿吨。

在美国，几个州已经实施了自己的碳定价举措。加州的总量控制与交易计划涵盖了电力、交通和工业的排放，而区域温室气体计划则对包括纽约州、马萨诸塞州和宾夕法尼亚州在内的东北九个州的发电厂的排放量设定了上限。

碳定价的影响

对碳排放定价似乎对减少排放产生了影响。

在欧洲，自 2005 年启动以来，欧盟排放交易体系已帮助该地区电力部门的排放量减少了43% 。

同样，加州的总量控制与交易计划也帮助该州实现了将碳排放量减少到 1990 年水平的目标。

在包括中国和加拿大在内的许多司法管辖区，计划通过增加碳成本或降低排放限制来加倍实施碳定价计划。

但是，尽管许多经济学家和政策制定者发现碳定价是抑制排放的最有效工具，但他们也指出，项目本身需要精心设计。限制过高或价格过低的举措以及给予某些主要污染企业豁免计划的举措都可能无效。

负责国家的文章《可视化世界太空碎片》首先出现在Visual Capitalist上。

太空碎片：地球轨道上的威胁

7月初，一个可疑物体被冲上西澳大利亚的一个偏远海滩。据报道，这块金色金属是一块返回地球的太空碎片。

而且它并不是唯一的一个。如今，数以千计的报废卫星、废火箭级、碰撞产生的金属碎片以及人类太空探索的其他残留物正以极快的速度绕地球运行。

在这张图中， Preyash Shah使用来自美国太空部队维护的Space-Track.org的跟踪数据来帮助可视化当前绕地球运行的碎片数量，同时确定造成这种天体杂波的最大因素。

注：许多用过的火箭体仍然受到其发射机构的主动跟踪和控制，并且来源单独跟踪它们。空间碎片包括失效且不受控制的废火箭体。

排名：造成最多太空碎片的国家

根据数据，截至 2023 年 5 月，大约有 14,000 个小型、中型和大型碎片物体漂浮在近地轨道上。这还不包括数百万个因太小而无法追踪的微小碎片。

尽管空间碎片是一个全球性问题，但某些国家在造成混乱方面发挥了更大的作用。 20世纪50年代，美国和俄罗斯（前苏联）以发射太空物体数量最多的方式引领太空竞赛。 20 世纪 70 年代，中国也加入其中，这三个国家的物体占了当今太空碎片的绝大多数：

*中巴空间碎片源自多年来的各项太空合作项目

俄罗斯的碎片数量（包括前苏联发射的碎片）目前为 4,521 块。但美国和中国也不甘落后，各有 4000 多人。尽管其中许多碎片是随着时间的推移而积累的，但在单个灾难性时刻会产生数以千计的碎片。

中国2007年的反卫星试验摧毁了自己的气象卫星，产生了3,500块空间碎片。同样， 2009 年闲置的俄罗斯卫星 Cosmos-2251 与运行中的美国通信卫星铱 33 号发生碰撞，产生了 2,000 多块碎片。

高速移动时，即使是微小的碎片也可能导致灾难性的碰撞。随着 SpaceX 等公司推出广泛的卫星网络，这些数字必然会增长。

地平线上更晴朗的天空？

解决空间碎片问题需要采取多方面的方法，包括国际合作、先进技术和负责任的空间实践。

科学家和工程师正在积极探索清理碎片的方法，包括天基碎片清除系统和新型脱轨技术等概念。

欧洲航天局等一些航天机构也在制定计划，确保其航天技术的设计符合安全处置计划，以显着减少太空垃圾的积累。

推动更加可持续的未来需要各种关键矿产来建设绿色经济的基础设施。然而，美国严重依赖非燃料矿物进口，导致该国供应链存在潜在脆弱性。

具体而言，美国至少 12 种被政府认为至关重要的关键矿产 100% 依赖进口，而中国是其中许多矿产以及许多其他关键矿产的主要进口来源。

该图使用美国地质调查局(USGS) 的数据直观地显示了美国对 30 种不同的主要非燃料矿物的进口依赖程度，以及美国主要从哪个国家进口每种矿物。

美国矿物进口依赖度

尽管美国在国内开采和加工大量矿物，但到 2022 年，进口仍占该国 51 种非燃料矿物消耗量的一半以上。美国地质调查局将净进口依赖度计算为表观消费量的百分比，显示美国对每种矿物的需求有多少是通过进口满足的。

在美国地质勘探局认为最重要的矿产中，美国 95% 或以上的 13 种不同矿产依赖进口，其中一半以上的主要进口来源地是中国。

这些都在美国政府的关键矿产清单上，共有 50 种矿产，其中 43 种矿产美国 50% 或以上依赖进口。

官方清单上美国 100% 依赖进口的其他一些矿物包括砷、萤石、铟、锰、铌和钽，这些矿物被用于多种应用，例如合金和半导体的生产以及制造业液晶屏和电容器等电子元件。

中国对镓和锗的限制

中国对镓和锗的出口限制于2023年8月1日生效，对美国各种矿产的进口依赖带来了新的挑战。美国镓100%进口依赖，锗50%进口依赖。

这些限制被视为对美国和欧盟对中国实施的制裁的报复，这些制裁限制了芯片和芯片制造设备的出口。

镓和锗都用于生产晶体管和半导体以及太阳能电池板和电池，这些出口限制给美国各种技术的关键供应链带来了额外的障碍，这些技术包括 LED 灯和用于高速的光纤系统数据传输。

这些限制也影响到欧盟，欧盟 71% 的镓和 45% 的锗从中国进口。这再次鲜明地提醒世界， 中国在许多关键矿产的生产和加工方面占据主导地位。

这些限制的宣布只是凸显了美国和其他国家减少进口依赖并使关键矿产和技术供应链多元化的重要性。

美国政府发布的《映射：失业工人与职位空缺》一文首先出现在Visual Capitalist上。

;

映射：失业工人与职位空缺，按美国各州划分

在美国，截至 2023 年 7 月，每 100 个职位空缺大约有 75 名工人可用。这意味着劳动力和可用工作之间存在巨大差距，但一些州也为潜在求职者提供了许多机会。

该地图使用美国商会的数据，显示了美国各州每 100 个职位空缺中可用的工人数量。

注：可用工人是指处于劳动力队伍中但没有工作、在过去四个星期内寻找过工作、目前有能力并可以工作的失业工人。职位空缺只是提供可用工作的所有未履行的职位。

过去三年中，佐治亚州的职位空缺增幅最大，该州 7 月份的每个空缺职位只有 0.57 人。但尽管空缺职位有所增长， 失业率去年几乎没有变化，在 3% 左右波动。

差距的原因

“如果全国每个失业者都能找到工作，我们仍然会有 400 万个空缺职位。” – 美国商会

据美国商会称， 当前劳动力短缺的主要原因是新冠肺炎 (COVID-19) 大流行，迫使超过 10 万家企业暂时关闭，并导致数百万人失业。

随后政府对失业者的支持和其他补贴使人们更容易呆在家里并脱离劳动力市场。商会的一项调查发现，自疫情大流行以来，五分之一的人改变了工作方式，其中 17% 的人退休，19% 的人转型为家庭主妇，另有 14% 的人只做兼职。

失业率最高的行业也是新增就业岗位最多的行业，休闲和酒店业的失业率最高（5.1%），领先于批发和零售业（4.4%）。

总体而言，尽管就业市场已开始有所降温，但招聘率仍超过离职率。 2023 年 7 月全国辞职率为 3.8%，而招聘率为 4%。美国有 980 万个职位空缺，应该为求职者提供充足的机会。

Total global debt stands at nearly $305 trillion as of the first quarter of 2023.

Over the next five years, it is projected to jump even further—raising concerns about government leverage in a high interest rate and slower growth environment.

As global debt continues to climb, this animated graphic shows data and projections for public debt-to-GDP ratios using the World Economic Outlook ( April 2023 update ) from the IMF.

Growing Global Debt Projections

After rising steadily for years, government debt first ballooned to almost 100% of GDP in 2020. While this ratio has fallen amid an economic rebound and high inflation in 2021 and 2022, it is projected to regain ground and continue climbing.

World government debt is now projected to rise to 99.5% of GDP by 2027. Here's data going back to 2005, as well as the forecast for global public debt-to-GDP:

Debt sharply increased in both 2020 and 2009 in conjunction with economic downturns. Historically, debt levels compared to GDP tend to increase as little as 4% and much as 15% in the five years after a global recession has ended.

In the US, public debt-to-GDP is set to reach a record 134% by 2027. The sharp rise in interest rates is increasing net debt servicing costs, which stood at $475 billion last year. Over the next 10 years, net interest costs on US debt are projected to total $10.6 trillion .

China's debt has also risen rapidly, and is projected to eclipse 100% by 2026. Public debt as a percentage of GDP is forecast to jump fourfold between 2005 and 2027. This year alone, new government debt issuance is projected to hit record levels. A large portion of this debt consists of infrastructure bonds that are focused on boosting the economy.

Low-income countries have smaller debt levels compared to output, which is expected to continue over the next five years. Despite this, 39 of these countries are in debt distress—or are close to it—as high interest rates add pressure to government balance sheets.

Are High Global Debt Levels Sustainable?

The good news is that 60% of economies are forecast to see their public debt-to-GDP ratios fall below COVID-19 peaks by 2027.

On the other hand, many large advanced and emerging economies, including China, Brazil, Japan, and Türkiye are projected to face steeper debt. In the US, payments on public debt have soared to record levels due to rising interest rates .

This comes as aging populations, slower economic growth, and healthcare costs are straining government spending, a trend seen across many advanced economies.

Countries with economic growth rising faster than real interest rates may be more likely to sustain high debt levels. But sticky inflation, prompting higher interest rates, will likely make these debt piles even more fragile.

The ninth edition of the FIFA Women's World Cup that kicked off this summer in Australia and New Zealand is expected to break records.

For the first time, 32 teams are competing at the premier international event for women's soccer, up from 24 teams in the two prior editions. And according to FIFA, the tournament is already on pace to become the most attended women's sports event in history, with over a million tickets already sold.

How has the tournament grown?

This graphic created by JVDW Designs explores the timeline of this tournament, from its origins with only 12 teams in 1991 to expansions during the 21st century.

The Origins of Women's Soccer

Though there are reports of women's soccer matches as early as the 1700s, the sport started to grow in popularity in 1895 thanks to the British Ladies' Football Club (BLFC), one of the first women's soccer clubs.

Despite receiving no support from soccer associations in the UK, the club held its inaugural match in London and then went on tour. They received a lot of attention in the press, both due to the sport itself and debates in Victorian England over women's rights.

After gaining in popularity over the next decades and even drawing bigger crowds than men's matches, England's governing soccer association retaliated by banning women's soccer in 1921. The stated reason was that “the game of football is quite unsuitable for females and ought not to be encouraged.”

Other countries followed suit over time, sidelining women's soccer from France to Brazil. It wasn't until the success of the 1966 Men's World Cup in England, which set records for attendance and was the first to be broadcast to other continents, that England and then other countries in Europe re-established women's soccer due to increased interest.

The FIFA Women's World Cup

After multiple international tournaments in the 1970s and 1980s, FIFA finally organized the inaugural FIFA Women's World Cup in China in 1991.

At the outset, the athletes participating in the Women's World Cup were not treated as professionals . In her 2019 book, sports journalist Caitlyn Murray details that uniforms were sometimes hand-me-downs from men's teams, and accommodations during travel were far from luxurious. Notably, the tournament also lacked prize money until 2007.

The Top Performing S&P 500 Sectors Over the Business Cycle

This was originally posted on Advisor Channel . Sign up to the free mailing list to get beautiful visualizations on financial markets that help advisors and their clients.

The business cycle fluctuates over time, from the highs of an expansion to the lows of a recession, and each phase impacts the performance of S&P 500 sectors differently.

And though affected sectors have different levels of average performance, any given period may see the outperformance of certain sectors due to external factors, such as technological advancements or high-impact global events (ie global pandemics, international conflicts, etc.)

The above graphic uses data from SPDR Americas Research to show the top performing sectors through the business cycle over almost 70 years.

The Business Cycle: Methodology

The dataset is based on the Conference Board's Leading Economic Index , which assesses US economic activity. This index includes 10 economic indicators that reveal typical turning points in the business cycle covering employment, consumer expectations, and financial conditions .

Overall from December 1, 1960 to November 30, 2019, the dataset covers:

  • 7 recessions
  • 7 recoveries
  • 12 expansions
  • 11 slowdowns

Returns are shown for all of the S&P 500 sectors with the exception of the communication services sector. This is because the sector was created relatively recently in 2018 and comprises previous technology, consumer discretionary, and telecommunication stocks already covered in the dataset.

1. Recession

Broadly speaking, a recession is a period of temporary economic decline characterized by two successive quarters of falling GDP.

During this period, consumer staples was the top performing S&P 500 sector, and the only one that has averaged a positive return. Utilities and health care, traditionally defensive sectors, followed next in line. Together, these sectors averaged 10% higher returns than the overall market during six of the seven recessions.

Real estate has been the worst performer during recessions, given its high sensitivity to discretionary spending as both household income and business activity tend to decline.

2. Recovery

A recovery is the phase following a recession where economic activity starts to increase and the economy begins to grow again.

Real estate outperformed all other sectors with an average 39% return. As monetary policy eases and interest rates fall historically after recessions, this makes purchasing real estate more affordable, in turn supporting the sector's performance.

3. Expansion

In this phase of the business cycle, the economy is growing beyond recovery. It is characterized by increased economic output, employment, and income.

Interestingly, market returns were the second-best overall after recoveries. Top sectors included technology (21%), financials (19%), and real estate (18%) as economic activity climbed to its peak.

The utilities sector has historically seen the slowest growth across all sectors as investors tend to favor cyclical S&P 500 sectors that rise with an expanding economy.

4. Slowdown

This phase is often considered a peak in the business cycle, where growth starts to decline, but the economy is not necessarily shrinking.

With 15% average returns, health care excelled during slowdowns. Often, investors reduce their exposure to cyclical sectors as they prepare for an economic downturn , looking for more defensive investments. Similarly, consumer staples saw strong performance on average.

The Case for Diversification

The above data highlights how having a diversified portfolio of investments can help reduce sector-specific risk given the distinct performance trends of individual sectors over the business cycle.
